Award.AwardTitle: RUI: Tectonic Development of the Yanshan Fold-Thrust Belt, Northeast China
Award.AbstractNarration:
This study investigates the complex, episodic development of an ancient mountain belt (the Yanshan belt), relics of which now form the rugged terrain underlying the Great Wall of China north of Beijing. Recent work in the Yanshan belt has begun to document a complex geologic history that includes multiple, cyclic episodes of crustal shortening, extension, and volcanism that took place from approximately 200 to 100 million years ago. The causes of this tectonic cyclicity are presently unclear (although multiple potential drivers exist), in part because the timing and geographic extent of each individual event is imprecisely known. The purpose of this study is to use field geologic mapping, sedimentary basin analysis, geochemistry, and radiometric dating (U-Pb zircon dating of volcanic and plutonic rocks, and detrital U-Pb and Hf dating) to better constrain the age and extent of the multiple events evident in the geology of the Yanshan. Resultant data would have bearing on major questions such as: (1) Can the variety of structures developed in the Yanshan be deconvolved into individual events that tie to discrete plate boundary processes, or is deformational complexity in the Yanshan the result of long-term, progressive deformation associated with multiple drivers?; (2) Can the magnitude of shortening be quantified in the Yanshan belt?; (3) When and by what process did lithosphere loss occur in the eastern North China craton?

Establishment of a robust tectonic history for the Yanshan region will place much-needed additional constraints on key events in the evolution of eastern Asia. These events include multiple continental collisions that were responsible for the early assembly of Asia, the initiation and development of the western Pacific plate boundary, and a mysterious loss of the ancient continental lithosphere that once underpinned the Yanshan belt and surrounding regions. This work may also yield insights into the development of mountain belts in general, including how crustal extension, compression, and volcanism interact in time and space during mountain building, how the continental crust and lithosphere respond to repeated magmatic and tectonic events, and how the lithosphere and mantle interact during crustal thickening.

This project is an extension of a long-term collaborative venture between the PI and Chinese researchers from China University of Geosciences, Beijing. The project will support summer research in China for DePauw University undergraduate students and foster collaborative relationships between these students and students from China University of Geosciences, Beijing. This project is supported by the Earth Sciences Division Tectonics Program and the NSF Office of International Science and Engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Undergraduate research students at DePauw University, in collaboration with graduate students at China University of Geosciences, have mapped the geologic context and determined the U-Pb ages of over 6000 zircons from samples of volcanic and sedimentary rock associated with Mesozoic crustal deformation in the Yanshan fold-thrust belt of northeast China. The single-grain ages, which were acquired by DePauw undergraduate students using LA-ICP-MS at the Arizona LaserChron Center (University of Arizona), are being combined with Lu-Hf geochemistry, geologic mapping, and basin analysis to produce a well-constrained portrait of how the crust of the Yanshan belt evolved during Mesozoic time.

This work indicates that the Yanshan belt experienced a long history of crustal deformation that began as early as 256 million years ago. Closure of the Paleoasian ocean, which once separated the crust of North China from volcanic arc terranes in Mongolia, destabilized at least the northern portion of the cratonic North China lithosphere and constructed a mountain belt near the present-day China/Mongolia border that eroded to produce coarse-grained sedimentary accumulations throughout the Yanshan belt. The collision between North China and portions of Mongolia was one of a series of events that produced the Central Asian Orogenic Belt (CAOB), an accretionary complex between the Siberian and North China cratons that represents the largest zone of Phanerozoic crustal growth in the world. Crustal shortening in the Yanshan continued episodically until at least 146 million years ago, and was punctuated by extensional events in the Triassic and Middle Jurassic. Deformation in the Yanshan belt was driven primarily by accretion associated with construction of the CAOB, which ended with collision between the amalgamated North China-Mongolia block and Siberia to produce the Mongol-Okhotsk suture.

A prominent gap in North China magmatic activity from approximately 220-180 million years ago accompanied the extinction of an EW-trending volcanic arc along the northern margin of North China and the subsequent establishment of a NE-trending arc system parallel to the active paleo-Pacific margin. Major magmatic bursts in northeast China during the late Mesozoic, one in Middle-Late Jurassic time and another in mid-Cretaceous time, were likely due to arc magmatism associated with paleo-Pacific subduction. The mid-Cretaceous event caused widespread extension and thinning of the east Asian lithosphere.

This award funded summer field research in China, which was conducted by the PI and seven undergraduate students at DePauw University in collaboration with six Chinese graduate students. It also supported laboratory analysis of samples by DePauw undergraduate students at the Arizona LaserChron Center (University of Arizona), and student travel to national conferences to present their work.
